title: Practice – Using Prepositions with the Accusative (Motion Toward)
goals: Chant and translate accusative prepositional phrases
Combine them with motion verbs for complete sentences
Reinforce case endings and their meanings
Reflect on the virtue Ordō – Order

steps.speak: Salve! Welcome to Week 14 Day 2. Yesterday we met new prepositions like ad, in, and per. Today we practice using them in full sentences.
Chant after me: ad puellam (to the girl), in agrum (into the field), per viam (through the road), super aquam (over the water), ante domum (before the house).
Notice each noun ends with –am or –um. Those endings tell us motion toward.
Now let’s add verbs! Puella ambulat ad domum – The girl walks to the house.
Puer currit per viam – The boy runs through the road.
Agricola portat aquam in agrum – The farmer carries water into the field.
Mini quiz: Which case follows ad, in, per, super, ante?
Faith phrase: Ad Dominum currimus – We run to the Lord. Our words and actions have direction.
Virtue reflection: God orders even our motion. Latin shows that order through its endings.
Chant one more time: –a → –am, –us → –um. Motion toward means movement done!
Bene! Tomorrow we’ll learn how prepositions can also show rest or place — with the ablative.
